body.p: In spite of the unfortunate event of my late effort Charles the First, I still wish to make another attempt at Historical Tragedy, wrote Mary Russell Mitford on 18 December 1825. She addressed this missive to George Colman, the London theatre playwright, manager, and advisor to the Licenser of Plays. Mitford planned to dramatize the conflict between the medieval Archbishop Thomas of Becket and King Henry II, who apparently arranged Becket's assassination. Before writing this work, Mitford wished to know if Colman would approve of its presentation. Your opinion, or rather your advice, whether for or against the play is all I ask, she assured him. She would be equally grateful for his approval of the idea or his kind warning to desist. Mitford 413

Mitford had reason to worry that Colman might find her attempt at Historical Tragedy objectionable, and even unproduceable. A few weeks earlier, he had advised the Licenser, Lord Montrose, to reject Mitford’s completed Tragedy of Charles the First. On 29 September 1825, Colman informed Montrose that Mitford's title brings, instantly, to mind the violent commotions of the Caroline era, and, more dangerously exhibits the fanatical manners (mores) and puritanical cant of Oliver Cromwell and his associates. Also, she blasphemously employs Scriptural allusions, & quotations, and characters take the name of the Lord in vain Colman 408. Montrose concluded that the play is certainly not proper for representationGraham 410 in a theatre. On 10 October, Colman duly suspended the play's license on account of its peculiar title & incidents Colman to Mitford, 409. In these two men's shared view, Mitford’s depiction of the events leading up to the Regicide could not be produced for public audiences.

That Mitford did not check with Colman before writing this play reinforces the impression that Montrose’s decision blindsided her. Perhaps it should not have. On Saturday, 26 January 1649, Charles Stuart, formerly known as King Charles I, was tried for High Treason, convicted, and sentenced to death. The sentence was carried out four days later, on a scaffold erected in front of the ornate Banqueting-House that had been designed for his father by Inigo Jones. Jones had also been a designer of stage sets, so the execution of the once-royal prisoner, who approached wearing densely bejewelled gloves, might have seemed particularly theatrical. But a generation later, in 1660, the English monarchy was restored, under Charles's son Charles II. In that year, the Act of Indemnity and Oblivion criminalized any discussion of the Regicide that might serve to revive the memory of the late differences, or to investigate any surviving Briton’s involvement in Charles’s deposition and death Norbrook 1.

This Act suppressed Commonwealth history well into the eighteenth century. For instance, the late-eighteenth-century descendants of one Regicide, Colonel John Hutchinson, embargoed his wife Lucy Hutchinson’s manuscript account of her husband’s exploits, her own political activity, and her hopes for a future in which their religious and political ideals would not be condemned. When the historian and Republican Virago Catharine Macaulay (1731-1791) implored the Hutchinson descendant Sir Thomas Hutchinson to publish the memoir, he refused See Hutchinson, J., ed., 'Preface'. It first appeared, with a profusion of Whiggish apology from Sir Thomas's nephew Julius Hutchinson, in 1806.

Despite the horror that the Regicide evoked during the Restoration, early in the eighteenth century it was the subject of a stage tragedy in which it carried a politically mainstream meaning. As Colman and Montrose knew, in 1737, the playwright William Havard had seen his King Charles the First, An Historical Tragedy produced at Drury Lane. In 1737, Charles I was generally associated not with tyrannical monarchy, but with treason against the new Hanoverian dynasty, because his brother's descendants and self-proclaimed heirs, the Old Pretender James Francis Stuart and Young Pretender, Charles Edward Stuart (also known as Bonnie Prince Charlie) threatened Britain with invasion. This threat the Stuart faction carried out twice, in 1715 and 1719, and would attempt for a final time in 1745. In this context, Stuart typically meant traitor. The late eighteenth-century evaporation of the Jacobite threat, observes critic Richard McCoy, made Havard's Charles a figure of pathos and pity McCoy 135. Thus abjectly humanized, the doomed king did not invite parallel with George II.

By the Regency, the meaning of the Regicide had again changed. The massive unpopularity of the mad king George III (d. 1820) and his successor George IV invalidated Havard's safeguards. One copy of the 1806 edition of Lucy Hutchinson's memoir, now in the collection of the University of California at Los Angeles, testifies to this change. In this copy, anonymous manuscript annotations likely written between 1806 and 1811Date of annotations estimated based on textual references to the future George IV, Prince Regent from 1811 to 1820, as the Prince of Wales. communicate horrified premonitions. The annotator sees horrid omens in the play's dedication to the Prince of Wales: omens, perhaps, that he would die by legislative fiat, as did Louis XVI of France in 1793. And then: The fanaticism of the writer [Lucy Hutchinson], & the Jacobinism of the Editor [Julius Hutchinson], render a steady perusal impossible. Yet it is dedicated with permission to the Prince of Wales! O horrible most horrible! See UCLA copy containing the notes of the anonymous annotator, which may be accessed at Internet Archive:
Later in the Regency, Sir Walter Scott created a new narrative of the defunct Jacobite struggle. In this narrative, George IV inherited the Stuart claim to the British throne and even earned a dubious Scottish cultural identity by dint of his distant Scottish ancestry and the apparent will of the people of Edinburgh, through a royal visit that had been carefully stage-managed by Scott McCracken-Flesher 109.

Meanwhile, voices of reform began to put the suppressed memory of the Regicides to new and radical use. In 1819, Percy Bysshe Shelley began writing another tragedy based on Charles the First. As Nora Crook demonstrates, this radical political drama deprecates both Charles and Cromwell, and explores the utopian potential of the Commonwealth envisioned by the complicated rebel and republican martyr Sir Henry Vane. Why Shelley abandoned this play is unclear, but he wrote in frustration of his sympathy for Charles, suggesting that his envisioned Regicidal drama was self-censored Crook, Calumniated Republicans 163-165; see also Crook, Shelley's Late 300-301.

While Shelley’s Charles the First fulfilled a political exigency, Mitford was drawn by the subject’s potential as a vehicle for the actor-manager William Macready. To Mitford, Cromwell was one of the most remarkable creatures that ever figured in the great Theatre of LifeSee Mitford's 1834 Preface to Charles I. Modern historians agree: as Alan Marshall contends, few men in the past have attracted more enthusiasts and detractorsMarshall 7. Macready tended to play rebels and despots, including Richard III; the pseudohistorical Swiss revolutionary William Tell; Lord Byron's doomed Oriental tyrant Sardanapalus; and the Cardinal Richelieu, the posthumously infamous architect of Louis XIV's France, who is now perhaps best known as the villain in The Three Musketeers.

At the same time, Mitford's Charles the First is not apolitical. Diego Saglia has demonstrated that many plays produced in the London patent theatres during the 1820s opening of the Age of Reform investigate the concept of liberty, and Mitford’s are no exception. As Saglia points out, her Rienzi, inspired by the medieval Italian rebel (or demagogue) Cola di Rienzo, fits this description. So does Charles the First, whose characters attempt to balance different sorts of liberties—domestic as well as political and spiritual , 'The Talking Demon' 363. In this play, Cromwell claims to represent the people of England, but privately nurses tyrannic ambition. Mitford indicates this hypocrisy early in the drama, by giving Cromwell conspiratorial asides reminiscent of those of Shakespeare's (and Macready's) Richard III. For example, while Cromwell allows his New Model Army comrades to brainstorm ways to deal with the deposed king, and one, Major-General Sir Thomas Harrison suggests exiling him like the Biblical king Amaziah, Cromwell remarks (Aside) Ha! And they slew him [Amaziah]! Thus Cromwell diabolically deciphers Harrison's unspoken wish, then engineers its dread fulfillment as a communal act. And yet, he also persuasively champions political liberty. He warns the would-be Regicides that should Charles survive, he will avenge himself. Then:

quote.l: The liberty for which the blood of saints
And martyrs hath been spilt, freedom of act,
Of speech, of will, of faith!

body.p: Surely this is a paean to liberty, no matter its motivation.

Mitford's representation of Charles seems equally diplomatic. Charles’s complicating humanity apparently catalyzed Shelley’s internal censor, but Mitford embraces psychological and moral complexity, making Charles at once a loving father, an impassioned husband, and a disastrous king. Henrietta Maria, Charles's French queen, displays similar depth--and frequently steals the scene. Anachronistically styling herself a Gothic heroine, Henrietta Maria stalks castle corridors in search of her imprisoned love, rails at his enemies, and, when she finds him, offers to trade her life for his via a ruse that strongly anticipates Sydney Carton’s redemptive self-sacrifice in A Tale of Two Cities, which Charles Dickens would not write until four years after Mitford’s death.

When Mitford's rich dramatic tapestry failed to impress Colman and Montrose, Mitford revised it, and it was finally staged and published in 1834. By then, the climate had become more favorable. In a new preface, Mitford claims that although her work was never revolutionary, [...] against such a king as William IV, rebellion's shafts would fall harmless. (How they might have struck George IV in 1825, she does not speculate.)

Still, the unfortunate event that linked Mitford's play with English Republican transgression may have kept haunting her. In 1840, the struggle for various kinds of reform, including working-class male suffrage, had culminated with the composition of the People’s Charter and its presentation to Parliament. Its suspected primary author, William Lovett, was serving a three-year sentence at Warwick Gaol for having allegedly incited Chartist demonstrators at Birmingham’s Bull Ring to violence. Mitford was writing on commission again, this time for the ornate illustrated compendium Finden’s Tableaux. The Roundhead’s Daughter makes it clear where her sympathies lie with regards to the English Civil War, the Commonwealth, and the Regicide. In this story, Mitford’s Parliamentarians are Puritans, and are stereotypically Puritanical. The heroine, Mabel Goodwin, wears the pinched coif and demure kerchief of the Puritans, squandering her beauty 36. Also squandered by the Commonwealth-men are England’s land and cultural heritage. In 1658, the English countryside is characterized by neglected desolation, and the heroine’s suitor’s father, the disenfranchised Cavalier Lord Philip Montresor, has seen his magnificent mansion, where the Virgin Queen once danced with his ancestor, stolen by the Committee of Sequestration and bestowed upon Mabel’s father, Colonel Goodwin, a plain soldier and zealous Roundhead36. Luckily, Mabel defies her father and Cromwell’s regime to marry her nobleman, and, after the Restoration, Lord Philip magnanimously saves the Colonel and facilitates the reconciliation in tranquillity of the formerly warring factions. Like the ending of Waverley, that of The Roundhead’s Daughter preaches reconciliation in a context favorable to the Hanoverian victors. Also uniting morality (Good win[s]) with wealth (Montresor means my treasure), Mitford lets her audience know that in the Victorian era, the dissensions of the Civil War have been completely healed.

Only that was perhaps an optimistic view. Even in the twentieth century, physically simulating the corporeal reality of the Regicide on the mainstream London stage remains taboo. In the 2012 Hampstead Theatre, London premiere of Howard Brenton’s play 55 Days, the executioner lifts his axe above the deposed king, but before the blade can fall, the curtain does. The continuing controversiality of this execution as stage drama compels us to reread Mitford's take—and perhaps to revive it.
